results.title: Viva Las Vegas = Love in Las Vegas
results.creator_credit: Jack Cummings, Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer and George Sidney
results.brief_description: Elvis Presley stars as racing car driver Lucky Jackson, a man determined to win the Las Vegas Grand Prix and triumph over his number one competitor, Count Elmo Mancini (Cesare Danova). The Count is like Lucky in many respects, a determined, thrillseeking ladies man, which makes defeating him even more difficult. To finance his vehicular obsession (and to purchase the most important item - the engine), he performs as a singing waiter, thus giving Elvis the chance to demonstrate his crooning and hip swinging capabilities. The task proves harder than first thought due to the distraction of sexy swimming instructor Rusty Martin (Ann-Margaret), as Lucky faces the prospect of losing love as well as the race. Elvis’ fourteenth movie includes hits such as “The Lady loves me”, “What’d I say”, “C’mon everybody” and “Viva Las Vegas”. Cast also includes Cesare Danova, William Demarest and Nicky Blair. Contains the original theatrical trailer.

results.title: Viva Falantil!
results.creator_credit: Pip Starr, SKA TV and Campbell Manderson
results.brief_description: Report on a group of performers and activists who stowed away on a UN flight bound for East Timor to raise awareness of the plight of the Falintil people and their 20 year struggle against the East Timorese military. A tour through a newly-independent East Timor, still shell-shocked and facing an uncertain future. This story examines the possibilities for and obstacles to building a democratic nation. Produced as a news story for SKA TV’s Access News, a grass-roots alternative to mainstream news and current affairs, broadcast weekly on Melbourne’s Community Television station Channel 31 since 1994.

results.title: Vitamin C
results.creator_credit: Michael Coyle and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Home Economics”
During the winter many of us suffer from a lack of Vitamin C. What foods are the best sources of Vitamin C and how can we preserve it in our cooking?

results.title: Vitamin 'A' from the sea
results.creator_credit: Department of Visual Aids, University of Melbourne
results.brief_description: With supplies of liver oil cut off from overseas during wartime, research was undertaken to find a local product as a source of vitamin concentrates. A valuable source of oil, often richer in vitamins than that previously obtained from overseas, was found in the livers of snapper shark caught in waters south of Victoria. The film illustrates the work of the Bass Strait fishing fleet and shows how the liver oil is processed at a Melbourne factory to produce the active ingredient used in a series of vitamin-rich products.

results.title: Vitalogy
results.creator_credit: Clare Sawyer, Film Victoria and Greg Williams
results.brief_description: Lissa is intrigued by the odd behaviour of new next door neighbours. Her curiosity grows into sexual attraction for Michael the awkward son, who although he performs a weird foot washing ritual at night, is virile and shares an increased sexuality with the onset of adolescence. Two worlds collide and the rituals of ‘vitalogy’ become unstuck as illness forces the new neighbours to face a different world. Cast includes Tenley Gilmore as the cool and confident Lissa and Stephen Pilkington as Michael (with Margot Knight and Brian Lipson). Winner Best Australian Short Comedy Melbourne International Film Festival 1991.

results.title: Visually speaking. Parts 1-6
results.creator_credit: Yaletown Productions Inc., ONF | NFB and Don White
results.brief_description: 1. “Body talking”. Begins the sequence by exploring the power of visual images as a source of information and means of communication. 2.”A sense of touch” 3. “A sense of sound”. These two segments extend the power of visual imagery by showing how it connects with information from other senses to enrich the meaning we gain from our experiences. 4. “Speaking object-ly”. Provides a transition from the literal interpretation of visual imagery to the more abstract concept that what we see carries implicit subjective messages. 5. “Sequence and story”. Shows how visual images are connected to one another and how our interpretations can be changed as we explore how our images of them are related to one another. 6. “Movie movie”. Deals directly with ways in which visual images can be manipulated to influence our thoughts and emotions.

results.title: Visual story telling
results.creator_credit: John A. Givins, Lynn John and KTV Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 9 of Series “Video tech”.
This program presents a structured look at the practice and technique of video story telling. It looks at the sequencing of shots and how they work to advance a story, the planning of shots, the shooting of a sequence and the placement of the camera when shooting. It focusses on continuity and the factors to watch when editing so that shots will flow from one to the other and not seem illogical in the finished product.
results.creator_credit_for_label: John A. Givins, Lynn John and KTV Productions
